criteria: Ability to Prove the Pythagorean Identity
descriptions: Does not demonstrate understanding of the Pythagorean identity.
Struggles to recall the Pythagorean identity or its components.
Recalls the Pythagorean identity but struggles to apply it.
Demonstrates understanding of the Pythagorean identity but makes minor errors in its application.
Correctly states and applies the Pythagorean identity in most cases.
Demonstrates a thorough understanding of the Pythagorean identity and can apply it accurately and efficiently.
Unable to attempt a proof of the Pythagorean identity.
Attempts to prove the identity but shows significant gaps in reasoning.
Begins to prove the identity but cannot complete the proof or makes major errors.
Presents a partial proof of the identity with some logical flaws.
Provides a mostly correct proof of the Pythagorean identity with minor omissions.
Constructs a clear, complete, and correct proof of the Pythagorean identity.
Cannot use the Pythagorean identity to find sine, cosine, or tangent values.
Attempts to find trigonometric values but demonstrates a lack of understanding of the relationship between them.
Can sometimes use the Pythagorean identity to find trigonometric values but makes frequent errors.
Applies the Pythagorean identity to find trigonometric values with occasional mistakes.
Accurately finds trigonometric values using the Pythagorean identity in most situations.
Consistently and accurately uses the Pythagorean identity to find trigonometric values, even in complex problems.
Does not consider the quadrant of the angle when determining the sign of trigonometric values.
Shows awareness of the need to consider the quadrant but struggles to apply it correctly.
Sometimes considers the quadrant when determining the sign of trigonometric values, but makes errors.
Usually considers the quadrant but occasionally makes mistakes in assigning the correct sign.
Correctly considers the quadrant of the angle to determine the sign of trigonometric values in most cases.
Consistently and accurately considers the quadrant of the angle when determining the sign of trigonometric values.
